title: How I Went From a 3D Artist to GM of a Billion-Dollar Game - Justin MacFarlane

rawLines.text: Josh McFarland. McFarland. McFarland
podcast. Thank you. Thank you. That's a
powerful name. Scottish. Scott. Yeah.
Thank you. I appreciate it.
So, so you're a GM of Jackpot Party
Casino. That's right. A pretty big game.
Uh, but I'd love to talk about that. I'd
love to talk about how you became a
general manager, how you worked at at
site site play for 17 years. I'd like to
talk about live ops. I'd like to talk
about how you introduce complex features
to casual audiences. But what I really
want to start this off with is in the
pre-recording. Mhm. You're you're taking
this podcast from Cedar Falls. Yes.
which for the unknown audience in
everywhere is is a 40,000 person town in
Midwest. Yeah. Iowa. Uh well, Cedar
Falls has been um for me where like I've
grown at the company is it's it's been
the studio where social gaming for
Sciplay really started off. Um it's
where Jackpot Party was founded, which a
lot of people don't know. It's where we
built the team originally. It's where we
first launched the product. Um, and what
happened was throughout COVID, um, we've
expanded the company, multiple over the
the last decade. Uh, going into Austin,
Texas, going to Tail Viv Israel. We're
trying to bring in product knowledge to
Jackpot Party. We're trying to bring
more experts um to the game team. And
so, we allowed ourselves to kind of, you
know, lean into the remote working as it
became a little bit more prominent in
the industry. our entire product team,
our entire analytics team was in Austin
and our entire development studio. Some
of the people that I've worked with my
entire career that I, you know, a lot of
my success I I dictate like around like
Michael Gasman who is our director of
engineering is based out of Cedar Falls,
Iowa. So you have the development team
here in Cedar Falls, Iowa where it's
always been and suddenly we had this
product and analytics team in Austin,
Texas. Um, which was great for the time.
We were making we were doing what a lot
of companies were doing co co just
making it work and you know we thought
there was this illusion that it was it
was something that was okay. It was all
right conditions. We were able to use
technology to be have able to have video
calls having conversations like you and
I are having right now. Like it was
feasible. It was something that was
sustainable. Um as a as a team I'm a
huge advocate like the product is a
reflection of the environment it's built
in. It's a reflection of the chemistry
as a team you have working together. And
you are starting to see that disconnect
not only in the product itself, but in
some of the strategies and then you
certainly see it in the morale of the
team and the understanding and just the
overall engagement. And what was missing
was really that just the thing I love
about making games in the first place.
It's just that connection working with
people and uh and and that spirit of
collaboration that it takes like because
it's it's making games. It's creative.
It's collaborative. It's it's
whiteboards. It's standing up. It's it's
it's it's energy. It's all that stuff
that goes into games. And that fourth
wall of trying to get people to work
together was just a huge barrier. So, it
was we made the decision in December and
uh it's kind of ironic because I'm
talking to you in a temporary office as
we invest in in the new studio and
remodel in it. like the environment is a
reflection of where we're at as a game
team because it's very much rebuilding
for for a team on jackpot party bringing
members from Austin Tech and asking our
product team members to relocate from
Austin um which is a really really tough
choice for a lot of those people and
some of the people uh who weren't able
to do it we made the hard choice of
prioritizing the team over individuals
and so that meant bringing new
leadership in and moving on from some
leadership because we said we want
people together you know one of the that
we believe in at Scyplay is playing
together and playing together is what
helps drive great gameplay. And so we
made the tough decision to move on. So
we're we're bringing building a new
leadership team on the game. Um we're
renovating the office space like so
there's a lot going on right now I guess
is is kind of where you're going at with
the question I should say. Was there any
business decision behind it? I think it
was uh you know there's a lot of like
data points like a lot of team members
we have a really really strong
production staff that leans into like
production data. So you can you can see
in stuff like in terms of like the gaps
in even just like work getting completed
and like the the time between stuff. So
there is certainly an element of that
type of data, but I have to say the
intangibles, the feeling is really what
drove it and really supporting the
development team. you know, that, you
know, the art team that's in Cedar Falls
already, the existing talent that we've
built over the years. Um, and probably
adaptt and at least from our standpoint,
maybe this is a little bit egotistical,
but uh it it's what Phantom or Sciplay
has done for years. Like for 15 years,
we've brought people who haven't had
necessarily experiment experience in the
game industry, but they had passion and
they had raw talent and they had drive.
And that's what like as a business it's
like let's get back to what was growing
talent what worked for us 15 years ago
what worked with us a decade ago and and
now you're in a stage where you've
changed the uh the locations you're
integrating your team to work out of
Cedar Falls. How did you manage to do
this transition and how did you manage
to keep the business up and going and
growing?
It's a little rocky I tell you uh as
good as we could um you know because at
that same point you know you're
transition you're identifying who is
going to be able to make that jump so
you have to answer who is going to be a
part of the team uh and then you have to
continue to run the business in the
short term. Um, we just fortunate a
couple of the members actually yesterday
was their first day in office and it was
it was like the payoff, the reward was
right there. Like you saw it. You saw
everybody like like literally like
high-fiving, hugging, happy to be
together, be one another. Um, but how we
tried to manage this, we we try to say,
hey, we've come out and said that's
important for people to work together.
People obviously can't move in a day, in
a week. We have to have a an onboarding
process. So, we try to get people to
come up and visit at least a couple
times for a weekend and to start that
process. Um, with that, there was a lot
of just, okay, this is a new leadership
group that we're building. This is a new
game team. We have to run the dayto-day.
So, there's some things that we have to
do. We're probably doing that a little
bit more top down in terms of the
strategies that we're putting out, in
terms of the decisions that we're
making, but it's a good opportunity for
us to just look at all of our processes,
all of the things we do as a game team,
and just re-evaluate like is that the
right way for us to do it? We're talking
about things like, you know, how do we
build our live ops calendar? Who what do
those those phases look like? Um are
they as efficient as they could be? Do
they serve a purpose? Do they serve the
team? Um, so there was a lot of just
kind of rebuilding some of those
processes just because it's different
people who are going to be involved with
the process and people have different,
you know, expertise. They have different
ways that they want to do things.
Another thing that I really wanted to
hear from you is like how come you've
been at site play for 17 years? That's
not normal.
You know, I started in art and UI
design, 3D modeling. That's it's
probably not a consistent GM path to to
be honest. And if you would have told me
I would have been at slots for 17 years,
I would have said I would not have
expected to do that. And once I
graduated, I moved back home and I
started shipping out my demo reel to
different studios across the world
looking for that first gig. And by
chance, I found at the time what was
called Family Effects, which was a small
game studio that uh basically made at
the time they made slot games that were
just sold brickandmortar stores like at
Walmart for like $20. It wasn't free to
play, wasn't mobile. Mobile games
weren't even a thing. This was back in
2008, so it was a long time. And so I
was brought in basically to do UI work,
to help do menu design, um, and art
background. Um, but I'm the type of
individual I love to learn. I love
challenges. I love that. That's what's
rewarding to me is trying to do new
things. And so, um, when I was working
at the studio, one, I just love the
people. So, when you love the people you
work with, you that's the number one
thing. It's it's going to be always hard
to leave a place like that because you
you learn to work with different people.
And two, this was right around the time
that the studio was explored and doing
new things. And one of those new things
was was uh Facebook gaming at the time.
Like somebody like Josh was on the
podcast. I don't know if he's ever told
the story uh about how we built Jackpot
Party, but it was literally like three
guys. Uh I was brought into UI at the
time and in art. Uh we had an engineer
whose name is Forest Stow. He's now the
CTO of the company and Josh was
effectively our product manager at the
time and uh we saw a game had a game on
Facebook. It was using Unity and we just
said, "Hey, can we can we put it on? Can
we do that?" And I'm I'm really
shortening the story. Obviously, there's
a lot of details that I I don't want to
leave out or anything like that, but it
there was no expectations with that
project. It was just trying something
new and and obviously it became
something that blew up. And I I kind of
love to tell the story where like
everybody's celebrating around the DAU,
the revenue, how quickly the game is
getting adopted. Meanwhile, poor Forest
is having like a like a meltdown because
he's trying to build the server
architecture on the fly. And it turned
into something that nobody really
expected. And I think the reason I tell
that story is because that's what I love
about the company. It's always never
been afraid to try new things. It's
never been afraid to innovate. And so my
growth is a reflection of the company's
growth because it's always been an
opportunity as if you're the right
person with the the right passion and
the right thirst to learn and and try to
be challenged. It is the best
environment in mobile gaming. I mean and
maybe honestly in any industry if you
ask me. So when people ask me how have
you been at the same company for 17
years? My answer is usually like why
would I ever leave? I've been
challenged. I've had career development.
I've been able to tackle new projects. I
work with some of the most talented
people in the industry and every day I
get to learn something new. Um it's a
incredibly rewarding experience. I'm I'm
a very fortunate person. So that's you
know that that's the answer I give
people when I talk about why I've
worked. So from a 3D artist to
eventually a general manager over seven
well not 17 years. So first seven years
you were an art track and then somehow
you pivoted to general management. Can
you can you talk a little bit about like
to somebody who's three years in in
their company who is a 3D artist or an
animator or even an art director like
how do you move from that position to
general management what are the
important elements that you looked into
and overall how do you think about
career change because going from an art
track to a business track is just
resetting your progress. Sure. So I'm
just curious of like how did your
decision-m go and what were the steps
that took you to such a drastic career
choice? So I think the the first jump I
made really was from art to like
production based like maybe not so much
project management but production in
terms of like we talk about why I
personally liked getting into the
industry was like working with different
people of different backgrounds to make
something reality. That was my passion.
I love doing I like working with people
and I like taking something that's an
idea to reality and that fell very in
line with production. They needed
somebody to say hey we have a whole lot
of people who want to do something cool
but we need somebody to kind of bring it
together almost like uh Eddie Dorsy who
is a phenomenal uh uh production mind at
the company says somebody who could be
the glue for the operation. um just and
that's something that I think naturally
kind of falls into my personal
wheelhouse. But in terms of like trying
to take that step and with the steps I
had to do, I think the biggest thing is
just taking the time to learn. Um, and
that's something like I'm a very curious
person and I I would advocate to anybody
like you know the number of hours I've
spent outside of the normal nineto-5 of
just learning things like learning Jira
which is not the most exciting thing in
the world like like I I I know enough
about it but like it's it's I'm almost
don't get atlassian and mad at me but
like it's it's like the nerdiest part of
the job. Um but to have people who have
that knowledge it makes an impact on the
game team. It helps the cause. helps us
bring our vision together. Um, and so
naturally, like I I try to advocate like
don't get so focused on where you want
to be. Focus more on the things you want
to learn and where you want to improve
and the rest can take care of itself.
Like if you're somebody who's like, I
want to learn that. I want to understand
that. I want to question that. I want to
challenge that. Those are the type of
things I think that have helped me
personally. And the people that I've
seen be successful around me as well are
people who don't just wait, you know, to
to to be taught or instructed, but
looking for gaps in the organization,
looking for gaps in their own knowledge
space and and just trying to be
proactive about learning. Um, and that
is what Scyplay tries to do. tries to
provide opportunity for people who have
that passion to learn and improve their
career and learn things outside like
like you know if it doesn't matter if
you're in QA and you want to learn
production there's tracks there where
they can go out and find that
information we built around like the
LinkedIn learning platform and built in
our own like uh Nick Elliot and and Matt
Beecher at the company are working on
something called Scipplay Academy which
provides all this video content to
anybody that's out there to just learn
how to do things that are outside of
your wheelhouse.
Because the more well-rounded we are as
a team, the better we are going to be as
a team. And that also helps people make
those type of jumps. How do you take
what what kept you at side play
empowerment and ambition of of the
entire company? How do you kind of
distill that to your team so that they
are as bought in to what you're doing
and they are experiencing the same
career progression or similar? Of
course, you start with a much smaller
company, but they're also experiencing
that that wide career progression where
you from an artist, you can become, you
know, general producer and general
manager. From a producer, you become an
artist. I don't know if that goes the
other way around, but but you know, who
who can't draw a slot?
For sure. Um, yeah, that's that's the
challenge. Um, because now like as a
team, we're what 72 people in Cedar
Falls. It's it's a bigger like when I
started like I said it was three it was
me Josh and and Forest and then it was
Patrick we building analytics and it
grew but it was still always tightly
knit and suddenly you have this massive
team. So the ability to empower everyone
to that level of impact is is certainly
a challenge and it's just a
constant I was you know it's you know at
some points it's making sure you don't
make decisions for people. You don't go
too top down. You let the team fail. You
let the team have the opportunity to
make decisions. You let them grow. Um,
and that is a challenge because
sometimes like I'm I'm somebody who
likes to solve problems. So I will just
like jump in and try to throw every
solution I can think of and I have to
sometimes pause as GM because I have a
different role. My role is to pass along
that same empowerment that drives me.
And so it's it's probably tried to not
do that as much and let the team members
come up with solutions. let the team
members find where that next
opportunity, that next gap is and kind
of let them steer the ship and get them
the opportunity to have their voice
heard. The more we can do that, the more
sense of purpose we give the people that
have an impact on the team. Um, I won't
say it's easy because it's it's much
easier to just say, "Hey, I know what
the answer is. I want to do that or at
least I have a pretty good idea of what
the answer is." Um, so it's it's a daily
effort to do that. But that is the goal
is to make sure everyone has that same
level of empowerment, has that same
level of uh sense of ownership I should
say over the game that we have the
opportunity to operate. It's like a top
10 game. Millions of people play the
game every month. And uh and so the
opportunity to make that level of impact
is there. It's on us as leaders to pass
along that that responsibility and that
sense of empowerment.
What's the balance between you making
the, you know, direct decision and you
allowing the team to search for it? Uh,
it's it's recognizing the impact. Is
this a decision that will kill the
feature? Like, is this a decision in my
in my gut like it's just not going to be
successful? Um, so really it's it's
looking at the the impact and what we
can afford as a business. Um, and trying
to make some best guess guesses when
that is to make the decision versus when
it's not.
Well, interesting. So I last thing that
I wanted to talk about which is a big
thing is live bombs. Uh looking at
sideplay success like you've been
growing year over year since 2013 pretty
much no matter who owns the company no
matter if there's IDFA if there's not
IDFA if there's co if there's not co you
guys keep growing. Can you talk a little
bit how your live ops is structured and
what makes it so good? Yeah. Um well
it's it's still relatively Jackpot Party
is still relatively new. Like if you
look at the trajectory of the game um
you saw a spike probably 2020 2021
somewhere. And honestly before that like
our live ops was very very thin. Like we
didn't even do like asset releases. We
didn't even do content releases. Um I
give a ton of credit to Daphna Benon who
came on to the project to help build our
live ops. Um, and so it's it was a lot
of learning for us, for me as a GM
because I had to learn about what live
ops was, what drove it, and we had to
build basically mechanisms to be able to
understand what move players behavior,
what kind of challenges they like to
engage with. Um, really as a game team
and the number one goal for live ops is
engagement based. And I don't think I'm
the first person is like how do we we
create a situation and environment where
the game feels fresh every single day
and there's something you new and unique
to be able to challenge the player with
based on where they're at from a a
currency standpoint. And so for us over
the last uh couple years there's there's
a number of different angles to talk
about live ops. There's the strategy of
how we build our roadmap, how we build
our calendar, how we build the
promotions in game, how it all works
together. There's how we measure it,
which is what we have we spend a lot of
time considering like in terms of what
is effective in game, what isn't. And
there's honestly even the logistics of
live ops. Like as a game team, like we
had to go from a team that was very uh
project based and planning long-term
projects. They're used to building
things over time to suddenly we're
making pivots and changes in the live
game like on an hourly basis, which is a
lot of thrash for a development team to
be able to do that type of to reaction.
Um, so we had to basically sit down with
the team and make sure they understood
the impact that we make. Make sure we
gave the context to the decisions we
were making when we're making a pivot
when we're adding a new promotion. Um, I
think one of the things that helps
Sciplay be successful in the live ops
space is not only how they recognize the
importance of live ops in general, like
how the game must be fresh, how it must
be a live game and it's a destination,
but also their sense of urgency and
ability to analyze and evaluate how
effective it is. So, there's a lot of
talented people who who build, you know,
obviously the right way to evaluate and
look at the game on an hourly basis
versus our expectations. understand how
our players are interacting with the
game and understand what's working or
what isn't and then we're not afraid as
an organization to react and make
changes like like that and very fast. Um
and over the past couple years we we've
built processes like leaning more into
conbon and lean processes that allow the
team to pivot very quickly um and then
build the right tooling to be able to
support that type of thing. So like
admin tools, being able to to change the
right levels levers. We have a ton of
proprietary um solutions to be able to
manage and operate the live game. I
could probably go on for an hour and
just ramble on about about live ops and
and all of the work that goes into
making it happen. Um but I think at the
end of the day, it's just the level of
importance that Scyplay puts onto it and
that's why you see us be so successful
in that space. But can you let if you if
you want to go a little bit more
practical level? Sure. Can you explain
what you do on hourly basis, daily,
weekly, monthly and quarterly? Like what
are the different elements of the live
ops that you focus on different time
spans like hourly is probably different
type of offers and yep you know just
just a little bit of concrete examples
uh to just understand
how how um how robust your live ops
engine and work is. Sure. So there's
there's different levels of strategy
that go into play with the live ops
calendar. We we look at it in terms of
like like a month is a series of
campaigns. Every single day is part of a
campaign and what we call like in terms
of like this is what the player is going
to care about on given day. So we will
sit down months in advance and we'll
plan out the whole month. We'll know
what important weekends, what's going on
from like are there holidays that are
going on? Um, and we know things like
our big meta features like uh party
cards, which is this big collectible
feature. It lasts three months. There's
there's milestones in that that fall on
certain days. Uh, we have our diamond
pass feature, which is jackpot parties,
battle pass that expires every month. We
know when that thing's going to end. And
so, you kind of identify your
cornerstones of of when big events are
happening in the game. And then you
understand your gaps like when there's
not a lot going on in the game, and you
say, "Okay, we need to get creative
here. We need to build something for the
player that they're going to care about.
Our goal is to make every day feel like
it's December 25th, like it's Christmas.
Like there's no such thing as a a boring
day on jackpot party. So, a lot of
effort goes into just the strategic side
of building out the calendar of laying
out the major events and challenges. And
then you kind of go into more like the
weekly planning of like, okay, we need
we know we're going to do challenges. We
know we're going to have these types of
rewards. Then you get into the
fine-tuning of like all the tuning and
the different like segmentation that's
going to happen and you evaluate where
the players are at currently in terms of
like their different currencies like
their bank rolls for you know we've got
things like bingo balls which ties into
our bingo feature. We've got things like
you know obviously coins are staple of
the economy but there's a like diamonds
which drives the progression of diamond
pass. There's all these different
currencies that the players care about.
And so finding a way to balance that
throughout the month is more kind of
like as you get closer to the month,
you're starting to work out those
details. And you're working with the art
team, our our phenomenal art director
Elliot Ling, to bring it all together
like in terms of like the vision, like
the creative side to the game. How do we
like what is it going to feel like when
the player comes into? So once we're
through the planning stage, then we go
into what we call the production stage,
which is we're building it. We're making
the configurations. We're setting all
the game events. Boom. We've got a month
of content ready for the player. That
the important thing is it doesn't stop
there. The important thing is as we get
to the week of, we're seeing where the
game's at from a business standpoint. We
see how, you know, how is revenue doing,
how is engagement doing, what are the
players responding to, what are they
not. And that's where I think one of the
most important sauces is we're not
afraid to make changes to the plan. Even
though we've had months of work in
pre-production that have gone into this
plan, we're not saying we're locked into
this. And so we'll make a series of
changes. We'll work with the game team,
which is why it's so important that
everybody's together because this has to
happen very efficiently. Um, and you
want to deliver that context to the team
face to face so you get all the
non-verbal cues and everything. And um,
we'll reddraft a plan. We'll make some
pivots. We'll add obviously we'll add
store sales, store logic changes based
on where the players are at, but we'll
do things like we'll tweak the events
that we're running. Like maybe players
are falling behind in their progression.
And so it's an opportunity to give them
rewards like more diamonds for their
diamond pass season. All sorts of stuff
like that um that we do on a weekly
basis. And then when it gets to hourly,
you are looking at things that like
either moving up sale times, changing uh
offers that you're giving players
because they're playing a lot more than
we expected over a given weekend. You're
either decreasing the level of
difficulty of challenges, you're adding
new challenges. you are adding stuff to
the calendar, but when we're talking
hourly, we tend to do stuff that's like
what we call like our canned we call
audles. I I don't a lot of us are
football fans, so it's almost like
calling an audible. Like, hey, there's
something different than we planned.
Let's call an audible. And then that
drives a okay, we need to retune
something and we get it into the game.
So, uh the team is is crazy. Like if we
can get an audible into the game in like
15 minutes from like conception to in
the player's hand. Um that's because we
lean on like pre-built like designs and
configurations that we can release at
given moments. What's what's an example
of an audible? Uh a great example is
okay. Hey um players are like engagement
is low. We we didn't actually know like
we didn't anticipate you. We're playing
the game. I guess I'm going to take a
step back before I answer your question
and just really underline the importance
of like as I play of also playing the
game. That's something that everybody is
expected to do. So as we play the game,
it's different when you're playing in
pre-production. It's different when
you're you're designing your whiteboard
solutions. When you have it in your hand
and you try to put yourself truly in the
player's shoes, you really you can
understand things that there are gaps.
And so some people play the game like,
"Hey, there's nothing really. it just
doesn't feel like there's something for
me to chase as a player. There's nothing
that like like I really care about. And
so a good example would be like we'll
add a quest that gives a player like a
wild card, which is like party cards.
It's a wild card is a very valuable
thing to the player because they could
substitute any collectible with it. So
if you're ever stuck on a set, you have
that opportunity. And if there's a low
if the game feels like it's just missing
something and it is in line with like
some of the data that we're seeing where
the engagement looks low, that is an
audible we might call where we add a
single quest for a player, a challenge
to be able to get this rare item and
then we would get that in the game
within within an hour. Um, and so we'll
respond to the data. Um, and I think the
reason I brought up the play side of
stuff because I mean Sciplay is called
Scipplay for a reason. It's part
science, it's part data, but it's part
play, it's part feel in the game. And so
there is a level of intuition sometimes
with those calls. Um, but you can
normally see it be backed by the data
